section.title: Review -- Derivatives and Linear Approximation
section.p: In the next activity, we will examine how to understand and interpret the force of interest as an instantaneous approximation. To prepare, we will review how the derivative of a function leads to the linear approximation for that function.

introduction.p: The derivative of the function y = f(x) at the point P is defined to be the slope of the tangent line:

figure.caption: The tangent line to a curve.

task.p: If the coordinates of the point P are known to be (x,f(x)), and we know the function f, why do we not have enough information to obtain the slope of the tangent line (assuming you do not know all that you learned in calculus)?

To find this slope, first we find the slope of a line "close by." This is the slope of the line between the points (x,f(x)) and (x+h, f(x+h)) where we think of h as "small." The line joining this two points is the secant line. Write down the slope between these points.
To get better and better approximations, what do we do with h? Use this idea to write down the definition of the derivative f'(x) at the point (x,f(x)).

statement.p: Use the definition of the derivative to prove that if f(x) = x^2, then f'(x) = 2x.
